title: Restricts the distribution of customer information by certain utility corporations
summary: Restricts the right of certain utility corporations to sell or otherwise distribute information concerning residential customers, subscriber names and addresses subjecting the same to regulations by the public service commission; prohibits such utility from disclosing and marketing certain other information about its customers; permits a violated customer to bring an action against such utility and imposes a fine of not more than $500 for a violation.

BILL NUMBER:S2586

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public service law, in relation to restricting the
distribution of information pertaining to customers which a gas
corporation, electric corporation, steam corporation or water-works
corporation may disclose

SUMMARY:
The purpose of this bill is to ensure the privacy of public utility
customers. Under the bill, the Public Service commission would
regulate the sale by utility corporations, as defined in the proposed
law, of customer mailing lists consisting of residential customer or
subscriber names and addresses.

However, a utility would be prohibited from disclosing or marketing
the following information:

(a) the customer's service usage patterns, including any energy audit
information;
(b) the customer's social security number, credit rating or other
personal financial information;
(c) services obtained from the corporation;
(d) demographic information; and (e) any other information determined
by the PSC.

Prior to marketing or disclosing customer lists, utility corporations
must provide customer notification of the practice and provide a
service bill check-off mechanism or opt-out provision whereby
customers or subscribers could restrict the sale of their names and
addresses. The Public Service Commission may require additional
notification or other conditions on the sale of mailing lists. Any
person injured because of a violation of the provisions of this
section could bring an action in their own name to recover the
greater of their actual damages or $500, to enjoin the continuation
of such violations, or both. The court could, in its discretion,
impose treble damages for knowing and willful violations. Prevailing
plaintiffs could be awarded reasonable attorney's fees. In addition
to the other remedies, any corporation which violates any provision,
shall be liable for a civil fine of not more than $500 for each
violation. The existing authority of any court, department or agency
to regulate the practices of public utilities would not be limited by
this bill.

EFFECTS OF PRESENT LAW WHICH THIS BILL WOULD ALTER:
The public service law is amended by adding a new section 119-d.

JUSTIFICATION:
With the advances in computer technology, information access and
database management, public utilities have begun to compile and

market lists consisting of their customers' names, addresses and
other data to third parties. The information is often combined in
predetermined configurations or profiles without the knowledge or
consent of customers. The information is sold and then resold for
purposes not originally intended. This practice has serious intrusion
implications. In fact, knowledge of personal information such as a
social security Number enables individuals and businesses to access
other data banks of sensitive information. Numerous nationwide
studies have revealed that Americans are increasingly concerned about
their personal privacy and the use of personal information stored in
files.

In
TRENDS AND FORECASTS TECHNOLOGY AND CONSUMERS:
JOBS, EDUCATION,
PRIVACY by Cambridge Reports, over 91% of those
sampled indicated a
concern for their personal privacy. In an American Express study, 80%
of those surveyed believe that corporations should not disclose
personal information to third parties. Finally, in a 1990 survey
conducted by Harris, 'over 70% of those sampled indicated that
consumers have lost control over how personal information is
circulated and used.

Furthermore, while some indicated their approval for selling customer
lists they conditioned that consent on the ability to restrict the
release to certain third parties or having the opportunity to opt-out.
In addition to the findings of recent surveys, empirical evidence has
demonstrated the fact that consumer resistance to database marketing
is increasing. Chesapeake, Potomac and New York Telephone Companies,
for example, reversed decisions to market and rent their customer
listings due to the overwhelmingly negative reaction from customers
concerned about their privacy.

FISCAL IMPLICATION:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the one hundred eightieth day after it
shall have become a law; provided, however, that effective immediately,
all actions and procedures with respect to the proposed adoption,
amendment, suspension or repeal of any rule or regulation necessary
for the timely implementation of this act are directed and authorized.
